'''Roosevelt Sykes''' (January 31, 1906 – July 17, 1983) was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[musician]], also known as "'''The Honeydripper'''".  He was a successful and prolific cigar-chomping [[blues]] [[piano]] player, whose rollicking thundering [[boogie-woogie]] was highly influential.<ref name="philbrodieband">{{cite web
|url=http://philbrodieband.com/muso_roosevelt_sykes.htm |title=Phil Brodie Band Tribute Page - Roosevelt Sykes |publisher=|accessdate=2006-11-26 }}</ref>

==Career==
Born in Elmar, [[Arkansas]], Sykes grew up near [[Helena, Arkansas|Helena]] but at age 15, went on the road playing [[piano]] with a barrelhouse style of blues. Like many bluesmen of his time, he travelled around playing to all-male audiences in sawmill, turpentine and levee camps along the [[Mississippi River]], gathering a repertoire of raw, sexually explicit material. His wanderings eventually brought him to [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]], [[Missouri]], where he met [[St. Louis Jimmy Oden]].,<ref name="Trail">{{cite web |url=http://www.thebluestrail.com/artists/mus_rs.htm |title=Roosevelt Sykes |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Thebluestrail.com |accessdate=November 19, 2011}}</ref> author of the [[blues standard]] "[[Goin' Down Slow]]".

In 1929 he was spotted by a talent scout and sent to [[New York City|New York]] to record for [[Okeh Records]].<ref name="russell">{{cite book |first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues - From [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]] to [[Robert Cray]] | edition= | publisher=Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | pages= 171–72 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> His first release was "[[44 Blues|'44' Blues]]" which became a [[blues standard]] and his trademark.<ref name="russell"/> He quickly began [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] for multiple [[record label|labels]] under various names including 'Easy Papa Johnson', 'Dobby Bragg' and 'Willie Kelly'. After he and Oden moved to [[Chicago]] he found his first period of [[celebrity|fame]] when he signed with [[Decca Records]] in 1934.<ref name="russell"/> In 1943, he signed with [[Bluebird Records]] and recorded with 'The Honeydrippers'.<ref>{{cite web
|url=http://www.aaregistry.org/historic_events/view/roosevelt-sykes-could-play-those-88s
|title=Roosevelt Sykes could play those 88's
|publisher=African American Registry
|accessdate=2006-11-26 
|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20061027023438/http://www.aaregistry.com/african_american_history/676/Roosevelt_Sykes_could_play_those_88s <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2006-10-27}}</ref> Sykes and Oden continued their musical friendship well into the 60s.

In Chicago, Sykes began to display an increasing urbanity in his [[lyrics|lyric]]-writing, using an [[eight-bar blues]] [[popular music|pop]] [[Gospel music|gospel]] structure instead of the traditional [[twelve-bar blues]]. However, despite the growing urbanity of his outlook, he gradually became less competitive in the post-[[World War II]] music scene.  After his [[RCA Victor]] contract expired, he continued to record for smaller labels, such as [[United Records|United]], until his opportunities ran out in the mid-1950s.<ref name="russell"/>

Roosevelt left Chicago in 1954 for [[New Orleans]] as [[electric blues]] was taking over the [[Chicago blues]] [[nightclub|clubs]]. When he returned to recording in the 1960s it was for labels such as [[Delmark Records|Delmark]], [[Bluesville Records|Bluesville]], [[Storyville Records|Storyville]] and [[Folkways Records|Folkways]] that were documenting the quickly passing blues history.<ref name="shaw">{{cite book | first= Arnold | last= Shaw | year= 1978 | title= Honkers and Shouters | edition=  | publisher=Macmillan Publishing Company | location= New York | pages= 14–17 | isbn= 0-02-061740-2}}</ref> He lived out his final years in New Orleans, where he died from a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]]<ref>[http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1980.html Thedeadrockstarsclub.com - accessed November 2009]</ref> on July 17, 1983.<ref name="philbrodieband"/>

==Legacy==
Sykes had a long career spanning the pre-war and postwar eras. His pounding piano boogies and risqué lyrics characterize his contributions to the blues. He was responsible for influential blues songs such as "[[44 Blues]]", "[[Driving Wheel (song)|Driving Wheel]]", and "[[Night Time Is the Right Time]]".<ref name="philbrodieband"/>

He was inducted into the [[Blues Hall of Fame]] in 1999<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blues.org/halloffame/inductees.php4?YearId=6 |title=Blues Hall of Fame Inductees - 1999 |publisher=Blues Hall of Fame |accessdate=2006-11-26}}</ref> and the [[Gennett Records]] Walk of Fame in 2011.

==Selected discography==
* ''The Return Of Roosevelt Sykes'' (Bluesville, 1960) 
* ''The Honeydripper'' (Bluesville, 1961)
* ''Piano Blues'' (Folkways, 1966)
* ''Blues Roots/Chicago - The 1930's'' (Folkways, 1967)
* ''The Country Blues Piano Ace 1929-1932 (Yazoo, 1972)
* ''Feel Like Blowing My Horn'' ([[Delmark Records|Delmark]], 1973)
* ''Blues by Roosevelt "The Honeydripper" Sykes'' ([[Smithsonian Folkways]], 1995)
